name: ANDARIEL – Maiden of Anguish  (BARD 5/ RDD 15/ PM 20)
author: Valerfor

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
This build needs neither fanfare nor advertisement.

There are many builds that use this combo but none with my level split or the AB & Damage of this one.

I have used this character in a more toned-down version in WoG and she performed superbly under all circumnstances, making the normally super tough Drow a complete joke.

Here she is the Maiden of Anguish herself.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
Valerfor wrote:Bonus epic feat list of RDD have Epic Prowess. That allows me to get full six GR. STR.
That is fair enough: 5 levels of RDD then give +1AB and +1AC, 5d12 HP and a minor dragon breath bonus.
An alternative is Armor skin instead of EP with +3 to AC rather than +1AB and +1AC.

5 more PM levels give +2 AC instead, if you just skip EP. You get 5d6+5 HP, an upgraded summon (lich lord), 2 bonus feats to spend on epic spells or epic summons, and (I believe) one more spellslot for your lvl 2 bard spells.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
I have played this build and enjoyed its brutal power. I took less UMD and maxed listen.
One thing I realized is that you can start with intelligence 12. I believe Valerfor took int 13 for the disarm feats. But because of the draconic abilities, intelligence jumps to 14 at character level 14. So you are OK when you start taking the disarm feats at lvl 15.
The spare point you get from starting with int 12, can be spent on charisma for an extra lvl 2 spell slot, or on dexterity to make it easier to fill the gap up to dex 12, for full plate armor.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I'm curious about a few things about this build in practice, Mick...

How successful is your spellbook casting in combat or were you just swapping the plate on/off for buffing?  I was assuming this build would be relying on items for casting without even Still Spell available. 

And how long are the buff durations outside of the Epic spells?  I'd expect them to be very short.

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content:
The spellbook casting is that of a level 5 bard, except that PM levels grant a few extra slots. So this build only has level 2 spells and lower. I have not tested if one could use level 3 and 4 slots for meta magic, since the build doesn't have any meta magical feats. And all spells with a somatic component must be cast "naked".
The duration of bard spells is as expected for a level 5 bard. The epic warding last 20 rounds and EMA 20 hours from the 20 PM levels.
I experience no UMD checks when casting from any kind of scrolls on hardcore difficulty. (modified UMD is 30)

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Ahh... thanks for the clarification, Mick.  Having never chosen to build or play a high-level PM myself, I was interested what the impact of PM levels was as compared to a wiz PM or sorc PM.

What I've found about Bard's version of UMD is that it is hard to set a level because it depends on the value of items your toon will likely want to equip.  The UMD value table helps to some degree in setting a viable target but some environments, typically the high-magic ones, place so many high-value properties on gear that, even with a net level of 40 UMD, your toon won't be able to equip them.  So it just depends.  As far as casting from scrolls, seldom are the highest-level ones valued over a few thousand gold, so 5-10 ranks is more than enough to use them all perfectly.

posts.author: Kalistez
posts.content:
Is it worthwhile picking up Taunt with this build, or are the dumps spaced too far apart?

If you shift your starting stats to 17 Str, 10 Dex & 14 Int, you gain an extra 43 skill points.  Then drop 1 Gr Str for AS then you get +2 AC, +1-6 AB(Taunt) at the loss of 1ab/dmg.

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
It would be worthwhile in a more defensive variant of this build. For example, if you had chosen to take a bastard sword & tower shield combo then I personally would also get her some taunt. But I can hardly imagine the environment that so much armour class is needed except perhaps in a high magic persistent world. And if you select to take "taunt", then go all the way with it and instead of taking "armour skin" go with epic skill focus "taunt" as your feat of choice.

You would also need to change the "disarm" feats for improved knockdown & toughness perhaps since those would compliment better the defensive variant.

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content: I'm so confused. What's the purpose of this build? Is it played as a more or less pure fighter, whacking enemies in the head with the scythe? There are almost no magic, unless wands, rods scrolls, etc that you find or someone else makes. Is it "just" a very intricate way to build a very tough fighter?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
A very, very tough fighter indeed. So tough that bosses on a medium-to-high-magic world have trouble hitting & the rest are simply out of luck. She is immune to a ton of things as well, sneaks, crits & fire included. She has magic via UMD of course, wands for darkfire, improved invisibility, keen weapon etc are all very useful to almost every fighter that isn't already a cleric hybrid & she can use them as well as anybody else. There was a revolution back in the day, I am talking about 2005 here (Neverwinter Nights history) when Ralkain posted a build called "The Pale Drake" in the legacy ECB forums & proved that this kind of build is so much tougher than a dwarven defender exactly because enemies can't ever hope to crit her or reliably hit her. That was an Elf & ended at 36 strength & had a rapier. It was a prototype of sorts. I took this and improved it by a lot & this was one of my first builds when I entered the ECB.

Also, I forgot to add her EMA ability (that lasts all day) when I was making the calculations for your server.
Her true AC: 47 (base w/shield) +10 (Armour) +10 (Shield) +10 (Amulet) +10 (Ring) +10 (Boots) +4 (Haste) +5 (EMA) +1 (Mage armour, stacks w/EMA)= 107 AC.
And then she has Epic Warding shield for 1000 Dmg absorption. And she can have Improved Invisibility/Displacement for an additional 50% miss chance via UMD.
Tough doesn't even begin to describe her...

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content: OK. A question: Is Disarm good in any way? I have NEVER in the last 18? years played with Disarm. Follow-up question: If I'm allergic to Disarm, what two feats do I take instead?

posts.author: neo.dietrich
posts.content: I've personally never found it useful. A lot of your enemies are going to be creatures that can't be disarmed. As for the dangerous enemies with weapons... there's usually a more useful action to take (like a regular attack at full AB).

posts.author: Mick Dagger
posts.content: If you have a bigger weapon then your target, you get an AB bonus.

posts.author: Mirnaia
posts.content:
It's not for removing the weapon from the opponent (that's just a corollary), it's for improving your AB when they wield a small (net +4 AB) or tiny (net +8 AB) weapon.
Whether it's worth two feats is up to debate, but the idea is to INCREASE your AB situationally.

EDIT: Ninja'd by the Ninja himself!

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content:
Mirnaia wrote: It's not for removing the weapon from the opponent (that's just a corollary), it's for improving your AB when they wield a small (net +4 AB) or tiny (net +8 AB) weapon.
Whether it's worth two feats is up to debate, but the idea is to INCREASE your AB situationally.

EDIT: Ninja'd by the Ninja himself!
Err... No? You get a -4 first, then a +4 or a +8. So you only get a bonus if you have a weapon two categories bigger otherwise you're even. This doesn't seem likely for a big boss. It definitely doesn't seem worth spending two feats on it.

I repeat my question: What feats should you choose instead?

posts.author: Valerfor
posts.content:
Yeah, it's what both Mick & Mirnaia said, for the situational AB bonus, but if you don't want to take it anyway (and it isn't useful at all in case you go for 107 AC, which means you'll have to use a shield) then IKD & Toughness aren't bad at all.
I would not take Expertise in that build because in all other PW's you don't need that insane AC and where you need it you ain't gonna hit consistently if you do.
If you want a dummy target though, then Improved Expertise & Toughness is a good combo.

posts.author: Cornflower
posts.content: I like the idea of a shield and warhammer (or Dwarven Waraxe) since it gives better AC and almost the same attack. On the other hand, I already have a toon that's a tank (DD with axe/shield) and one that's a DPS (WM with Hammer/shield) so I think I'll go with the scythe for fun, even if it's not optimal. (Although, you can argue, in a situation where the boss has high DR, it's better statistically with fewer hits with bigger damage, hence Scythe. Also, cooler.) As you say, the AC is kinda enough as it is. Also, IKD and Toughness it is.

posts.author: Cornflower

I made some changes, to adapt this for Blackstone Keep, where I play. Since the Epic Mage Armor only nets me +5 Dodge (the rest don't stack), I switched that for a mummy summon (which is buffed on BSK). Then I dropped 2 STR and got myself DevCrit (which on BSK gives +35% bonus damage). Also took Armor Skin, since the bosses on BSK have crazy high AB and if you wanna go tank, go full tank. I'm probably only gonna hit on crit anyway, so I might as well maximize my AC. Only thing I couldn't make myself do, was go Shield/Warhammer, which would have been better, but... The scythe is so much cooler. Oh, well. That decision cost me 9AC in return for slightly better crit and coolness.
